page.title: 20LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: {Fulmer's}name is derived from Fugelmere, a bird haunted mere. It was mentioned along with Datchet in the original Domesday Survey. It has always been surrounded by pasture rather than arable land. The original church was built on marshy land and rebuilt on it's preent site in 1610. The original medieval door is still there. The village pub sprung up from the workmen's hut at the time of the rebuilding. {Farnham}is derived from Fearnham, a village in the ferns. Thomas Gray's aunt was left{Stoke {Court}in 1742. He spent his holidays from Cambridge here. His Elegy in a Country Churchyard was said to describe Stoke Poges churchyard. He always feared fire in the mansion and slept with a rope ladder under his bed Fire destroyed the building in 1979.
